children.value: Do you wish your Gatsby blog posts could look like this when getting shared to Twitter?
iterates over your markdown files and automatically generates graphical representations of the frontmatter data! Itâ€™s highly customizable and can help increase your click rates.
Stackable Text Effects (opacity, drop shadow, stroke, pattern overlay)
of your website. This plugin only generates the card images, itâ€™s your responsibility to add the
. So make sure that you have

siteMetadata: {
    title: "My blog title",
    siteUrl: "https://mydomain.com", // no trailing slash!
  }

plugins: [
    // ...
    {
      resolve: `gatsby-transformer-remark`,
      options: {
        plugins: [
          `gatsby-remark-social-cards`,
          // ...
        ],
      },
    },
  ],
Note: itâ€™s typically recommended to have your
section inside your main layout component. I was unable to find a way to get the current absolute url from within the layout component, so I did the following.
(if you know of a better way to handle it, please open an issue or PR)
to your layout component and use that along with the
to get the absolute path to the twitter card.

const Layout = ({ slug, children }) => (
  <StaticQuery
    query={graphql`
      query SiteTitleQuery {
        site {
          siteMetadata {
            title
            siteUrl
          }
        }
      }
    `}
    render={data => (
      <Helmet title={data.site.siteMetadata.title}>
        <meta name="twitter:card" content="summary_large_image" />
        <meta
          name="twitter:image"
          content={`${data.site.siteMetadata.siteUrl}${slug}twitter-card.jpg`}
        />
      </Helmet>
      { /* ... */ }
    )}
  />
);
Then inside your blog post template, pass the postâ€™s slug to the layout

export default ({ data }) => {
  return <Layout slug={data.markdownRemark.fields.slug}>{/* ... */}</Layout>;
};
There are additional meta tags that can and should be used, although the ones I showed above are the only ones
to properly see the card image. For more information,
see the official docs for large summary cards
I built this plugin to be as flexible as possible, so at first the config may seem daunting. But keep in mind,
none of these settings are required
. You can add as few or as much configuration as you desire. All values shown below are default.

plugins: [
    // ...
    {
      resolve: `gatsby-transformer-remark`,
      options: {
        plugins: [
          {
            resolve: `gatsby-remark-social-cards`,
            options: {
              title: {
                // This is the frontmatter field the title should come from
                field: "title",
                // Currently only supports DejaVuSansCondensed
                // More fonts coming soon!
                font: "DejaVuSansCondensed",
                color: "black", // black|white
                size: 48, // 16|24|32|48|64
                style: "bold", // normal|bold|italic
                x: null, // Will default to xMargin
                y: null, // Will default to yMargin
              },
              meta: {
                // The parts array is what generates the bottom text
                // Pass an array with strings and objects
                // The following array will generate:
                // "- Author Name Â» September 13"
                // The objects are used to pull data from your markdown's
                // frontmatter. { field: "author" } pulls the author set
                // in the frontmatter. { field: "category" } would pull
                // the category set. Any field can be used as parts
                // Note: Only pass the "format" property on date fields
                parts: [
                  "- ",
                  { field: "author" },
                  " Â» ",
                  { field: "date", format: "mmmm dS" },
                ],
                // Currently only supports DejaVuSansCondensed
                // More fonts coming soon!
                font: "DejaVuSansCondensed",
                color: "black", // black|white
                size: 24, // 16|24|32|48|64
                style: "normal", // normal|bold|italic
                x: null, // Will default to xMargin
                y: null, // Will default to cardHeight - yMargin - size
              },
              background = "#FFFFFF", // Background color for the card
              xMargin = 24, // Edge margin used when x value is not set
              yMargin = 24,// Edge margin used when y value is not set
            }
          }
          // ...
        ],
      },
    },
  ],
This plugin is in itâ€™s early stages, so any and all help is warmly welcomed!
